Evenglare posted: "Axxelbox is a dumbass. Of course they could make a 48 fps version, video games routinely run a 60 fps. Fucking think before you speak you."

Unfortunately it's actually you who's the retard, Evenglare. The Blu-Ray standard dictates that the frame rate has to be 24 fps and if you put a 48 fps version on a Blu-Ray disc, no player would be able to play it back.

The fact that you can play a video game at 60 fps is something completely different and if you think the movie company would create a 48 fps version that only could be played back on a computer (i.e. pirated) then you are possibly the most stupid person on TPB.

Hey guys! 

I am really curious (and kind of pissed off) at something: why are there only a few HD movies with 1080p resultion, this is, 1920x1080? Whenever they are 1920x800 or x1200 they never fit the whole TV screen, wasting some movie experience.

For example, the last Harry Potter movie has no version ANYWHERE on the Internet offering 1920x1080 :'(

Why is that?

Thanks!

@juanchitoman, because when you talk about 1920x1080 you refer to the WHOLE screen. Not the movie. If it is shot as one of those that is really wide screen where on a 1920x1080 tv it has those black bars on it, then it is a different aspect ratio and everything. By default, those types of movies are not 1920x1080. So, when you encode that for a tv, you don't wanna waste the bits encoding the black bars, so you leave those out and you end up getting a 1920x800 actual picture area for a 1.77:1 movie. Don't stress so much over the resolution, man. People don't alter the movie when they put them up on here. It's all there.
